title: Synthesis and characterization of highly diluted polyanionic iron(II) spin crossover systems
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Synthesis of the triazol-based ligand (Me2NH2)2L)
Timing: 7 days
The synthesis of the ligand (dimethyl-ammonium 4-(1,2,4-triazol-4-yl) ethanedisulfonate) is divided in four main synthetic steps.
Synthesis of N,N-dimethylformamide azine dihydrochloride.
Add 150 mL of DMF to a 250 mL three-neck round bottom flask and introduce it into an ice bath.
After cooling down for 15 min, add dropwise 28.6 mL of SOCl2 (0.4 mol) to the DMF under stirring and with the necks covered.
Stir the solution for 24 h.
Slowly add 5 mL of NH2NH2·H2O (0.1 mol) to 10 mL of DMF and stir for 5 min.
Introduce the three-neck round bottom flask into bath ice and add dropwise the previous solution. The scheme of the reaction is shown in Scheme 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sch1].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2787-Sch1.jpg
Scheme 1. Synthesis of N,N-dimethylformamide azine dihydrochloride
Stir for 48 h.
Filter the yellow precipitate and wash it 3 times with DMF and 3 times with ethanol and diethyl ether and dry it under vacuum.
Analyze the product by 1H NMR (300 MHz, D2O): δ = 8.4 ppm (s, 1 H), δ = 3.4 ppm (broad peak, 6 H). Ethanol peaks might be observed: δ = 3.7 ppm (t), δ = 1.25 ppm (t).16[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib16]
Critical: These reactions are very exothermic. All the steps must be carried out in a fume hood. The filtration of the product must be performed in a Fritted glass (not paper filter).
Preparation of N,N-Dimethylformamide Azine.
Dissolve 20.5 g of N,N-dimethylformamide azine dihydrochloride (0.1 mol) in 100 mL of H2O.
In a different beaker, dissolve 10.6 g of Na2CO3 (0.1 mol) in 100 mL of H2O.
Slowly mix both solutions in a round bottom flask (Na2CO3 solution on top of the azine solution), Scheme 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sch2].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2787-Sch2.jpg
Scheme 2. Neutralization of N,N-dimethylformamide azine

Extract the N,N-Dimethylformamide Azine via liquid-liquid extraction with 750 mL of diethyl ether at 50°C for 48 h (See Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1] for liquid-liquid extraction set-up and scheme of the reaction).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2787-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Set up for the neutralization of N,N-dimethylformamide azine dihydrochloride
The organic phase extracts correspond to the neutral azine from the aqueous solution.
Concentrate the organic layer in vacuum until obtaining an orange powder.
Analyze the product by 1H NMR (300 MHz, D2O): δ = 8.4 ppm (s, 1 H), δ = 3.4 ppm (s, 6 H).
Critical: These steps must be carried out in a fume hood because H2CO3 gas is generated when Na2CO3 is added to N,N-dimethylformamide azine dihydrochloride and for the volatile diethyl ether.
Synthesis of 2-aminoethane-1,1-disulfonic acid (Optional).
Add 6.85 mL of acrylic acid (0.1 mmol) and 15 mL of acetonitrile into a 500 mL three-necked bottom flask placed in an ice bath.
Dropwise add 40 mL of fuming sulfuric acid (25% SO3) and stir for 30 min.
When the solution is cooled down at room temperature (20°C–25°C), reflux the solution at 100°C for 1 h.
Stir overnight (10–14 h) at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
The next day, place the bottom flask in an ice bath and add 85 mL of H2O.
Reflux the solution at 100°C for 24 h.
Place the round flask in the fridge for 48 h, see reaction in Scheme 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sch3].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2787-Sch3.jpg
Scheme 3. Synthesis of 2-aminoethane-1,1-disulfonic acid
Filter and wash with H2O, Ethanol and diethyl ether.
Analyze the product by 1H NMR (300 MHz, D2O): δ = 4.3 (t, 1 H), δ = 3.6 (t, 2 H). Ethanol peaks might be observed: δ = 3.7 (t), δ = 1.3 (t).17[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib17]

Critical: The fuming sulfuric acid (25% SO3) reagent generates high amount of SO3 vapors, and it should be opened in the fume hood. The reaction between the sulfuric acid (25% SO3) and the acrylic acid/acetonitrile mixture is highly exothermic, resulting in a rapid and locally temperature increase. Small explosion can be produced. Be sure the set-up is secure.
Note: The 2-aminoethane-1,1-disulfonic acid is also commercial, see key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table].
Synthesis of Dimethyl-ammonium 4-(1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)ethanedisulfonate) ((Me2NH2)2L).
Dissolve 3.0 g of N,N-Dimethylformamide Azine (21.0 mmol) to 20 mL of H2O into a 50 mL round bottom flask.
Add 2-aminoethane-1,1-disulfonic acid (1.5 g, 7.0 mmol) to the previous solution.
Add HCl until pH = 6.
Reflux the solution at 95°C for 19 h.
Remove the solvent under vacuum, obtaining a yellow oil.
Add 40 mL of ethanol to allow precipitation and keep the solution in the fridge overnight (10–14 h). See complete reaction in Scheme 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sch4].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2787-Sch4.jpg
Scheme 4. Synthesis of Me2NH2)2L
Filter the white powder, wash it with diethyl ether and dry it open air.
Analyze the product by 1H NMR (300 MHz, D2O): δ = 4.8 (s, 2 H), δ = 2.8 (s, 6 H).17[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib17]
Synthesis of FeII and ZnII coordination complexes
Timing: 7 days
The coordination of the ligand (dimethyl-ammonium 4-(1,2,4-triazol-4-yl) ethanedisulfonate) to Fe and Zn ions lead to the formation of linear trimers with formula (Me2NH2)6[(M3(L)6(H2O)6)] (M = Fe or Zn).
Synthesis of (Me2NH2)6[(Fe3(L)6(H2O)6)] (Fe3).
Dissolve 0.1 g of Fe(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.35 mmol) and a small amount of ascorbic acid in 5 mL of H2O.
Dissolve 0.3 g of (Me2NH2)2L (0.87 mmol) in 5 mL of H2O.
Mix the two solutions for 15 min, obtaining a pale pink solution.
For the obtention of a polycrystalline powder:
Add 20 mL of ethanol, leading to the precipitation of a pink solid.

Centrifuge the suspension (1900 × g) and decant the supernatant liquid.
Wash three times with ethanol.
Dry at 60°C for 2 h, see product in Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2787-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Picture of the powder of Fe3
Analyze the product via Powder X-ray diffraction in the 5−40o 2θ range. See next section, entitled: Structure of FeII and ZnII coordination complexes).
For the obtention of crystals:
Add 3 mL of the solution from section 5c) to a 5 mL glass vial.
Introduce the vial into a 50 mL glass vial.
Add ethanol in the outer space until the level of ethanol is higher than the inner solution (See Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3], left) and close the 50 mL vial (seal it with parafilm).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2787-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Pictures of the ethanol vapor slow diffusion technique for obtaining Fe3 crystals
Pink needle shaped crystals are obtained after 3–5 days at room temperature (20°C–25°C) (See Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3], right).
Analyze the crystals via single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD). See next section, entitled: Structure of FeII and ZnII coordination complexes.
Synthesis of (Me2NH2)6[(Zn3(L)6(H2O)6)] (Zn3).
The synthesis protocol for Zn3 is analogue to Fe3 synthesis.
Dissolve 0.12 g of Zn(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.1 mmol) in 5 mL of H2O.
Dissolve 0.3 g of (Me2NH2)2L (0.87 mmol) in 5 mL of H2O.
Mix the two solutions for 15 min, obtaining white solution.
For the obtention of a polycrystalline powder:
Add 20 mL of ethanol, leading to the precipitation of a white solid.
Centrifuge the suspension (1900 × g) and decant the supernatant liquid.
Wash three times with ethanol.
Dry at 60°C for 2 h.
Analyze the powder via Powder X-ray diffraction in the 5−40° 2θ range.
For the obtention of crystals:
Add 3 mL of the solution from section 6diii to a 5 mL glass vial.

Introduce the vial into a 50 mL glass vial.
Add ethanol in the outer space until the level of ethanol is higher than the inner solution and close the 50 mL vial (seal it with parafilm).
Crystals are obtained after 3–5 days at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Analyze the crystals via single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD). See next section, entitled: Structure of FeII and ZnII coordination complexes).
Synthesis of solid dilution Zn3(1-x)Fe3(x).
Dissolve the desired molar ratio of Fe3 and Zn3 (Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]) and 20 mg of (Me2NH2)2L in 10 mL of H2O with ascorbic acid.
table:files/protocols_protocol_2787_1.csv
Stir for 15 min.
Add 20 mL of ethanol, obtaining a suspension.
Centrifuge the suspension (1900 × g) and collect the solid.
Wash the solid with ethanol and dry it in air.
The actual Fe/Zn content was determined by EDX and ICP-OES (inductive coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy) analysis (see values in Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2]).
table:files/protocols_protocol_2787_2.csv
Analyze the powder via Powder X-ray diffraction in the 5−40o 2θ range. See next section, entitled: Structure of FeII and ZnII coordination complexes).
Structure of FeII and ZnII coordination complexes
Timing: 5 days
The crystallographic structure of FeII and ZnII complexes can be determined by combining single crystal and powder X-ray diffraction.
Single-crystal X-Ray diffraction (SCXRD)
Collect Single-Crystal X-Ray diffraction (SCXRD) data at 100 K with a diffractometer, Bruker APEX duo diffractometer with an APEX II CCD detector using Mo-Ka (λ = 0.71073 Å) and equipped with an Oxford Cryostrem 700 plus.
Obtain the crystal structure solution using SHELXTL and the XP program.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2787-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Representation of the molecular structure of Fe3 (left) and Zn3 (right)
Hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity.

Note: Both structures crystallized with high degree of disorders with one molecule of an anionic trimetalic complex, six dimethylammonium cations and five water molecules in the asymmetric unit, being Fe3 and Zn3 isostructural complexes (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]). (Fe3 CCDC deposition number: 1016539 ; Zn3 CCDC deposition number: 2019876).
Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD)
Perform PXRD to the Zn3(1-x)Fe3(x) solid dilutions in order to confirm the absence of local phase separation. In our case we used a Siemens D5000 diffractometer fitted with a curved graphite diffracted-beam monochromator, incident, and diffracted-beam Soller slits, a 0.06o receiving slit and scintillation counter as a detector. Parameters of the sequence:
2θ range: 5°−40°.
Angular step: 0.05° at 10 s per step and sample rotation.
Radiation source: Cu-kα from a copper X-ray tube operated at 40 kV and 30 mA.
Analise the PXRD patterns via Pawley profile refinement (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]) or via LeBail refinement. These refinements can be performed using TOPAS software or the open access FullProf software.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2787-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Pawley refinement (black line) of PXRD patterns (red circles) for Zn3(1-x)Fe3(x)
The green line represents the difference between fitting and experimental data.
Spin transition detection of the iron trimer (Fe3) in Zn3(1-x)Fe3x
Timing: 2 days
Magnetic measurements
The magnetic properties of the solid samples are measured via a superconducting quantum interference devices (SQUID) magnetometer. In this case, we used a Quantum Design MPMS-XL SQUID magnetometer (Quantum Design, San Diego, CA, USA) under a 1000 Oe field.
Sample preparation:
Weight an open gel capsule. Write the weight change in each following steps.
Fill the capsule with approximately 35 mg of the homogeneous powder. Introduce glass wool or cotton in the capsule.
Close the capsule with Kapton tape (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6] bottom).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2787-Fig6.jpg
Figure 6. Picture of the sample ready to measure in the SQUID

Make a 1 mm diameter hole in the top part of the capsule to facilitate the purge inside the capsule and allow the sample dehydration during the first heating process.
Introduce the capsule in a plastic straw (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6] top) and place it in the sample holder of the magnetometer.
For magnetic measurements, use the PPMS MultiVu software in RSO mode to create a sequence of 5 cycles at 1000 Oe between 200 and 400 K with different scan rates (2 K/min – 0.3 K/min).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2787-Fig7.jpg
Figure 7. Data correction process for magnetic susceptibility cycle of Zn3(1-x)Fe3(x) (x = 0.4)
(A) Raw magnetization extracted from the SQUID measurements. (B) Net magnetization obtained after correction of the diamagnetic contribution of the sample holder. (C) Magnetization per mol of iron trimer. (D) Final graph representing magnetic susceptibility temperature product (Xm·T) vs. temperature.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2787-Fig8.jpg
Figure 8. Magnetic susceptibility data in the 200–400 K range for Zn3(1-x)Fe3(x), x = 0.4 (blue dots)
The theoretical    χ M  T   value for 100% of FeIIHSFeIILSFeIIHS and FeIIHSFeIIHSFeIIHS is represented by red arrows.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2787-Fig9.jpg
Figure 9. DSC data during successive heating/cooling cycles for (Fe3); (Zn3) and the solid dilution Zn3(1-x)Fe3(x) with x = 0.5
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2787-Fig10.jpg
Figure 10. Evolution of powder X-ray diffraction patterns for Fe3, Zn3 and 5% Fe3 during a thermal cycle between 295 K and 420 K
table:files/protocols_protocol_2787_3.csv

Where XM is the molar magnetic susceptibility of the sample (cm3·mol-1) and Mm is the molecular weight of the Fe3 complex (2191.6 mg mmol-1).
Finally, represent the magnetic susceptibility temperature product (Xm·T) vs. temperature, Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]D.
Magnetic data interpretation.
Compare the experimental magnetic susceptibility data with the theoretical    χ M  T   values for an ironII trimer with two different configurations (FeIIHSFeIILSFeIIHS and FeIIHSFeIIHSFeIIHS).
These theoretical values can be determined by using this equation:
χ

Where N is the Avogadro`s number (6.022·1023 mol-1), g is the g-factor (typically g = 2 for ideal isotropic situation), k is the Boltzmann constant (9.27·10-24 J·T-1),   μ B   is the Bohr magneton (5584.8 cm3mol-1) and S is the total spin of the complex.
According to this equation, the theoretical    χ M  T   product for an only-spin FeIILS is 0 and for an only-spin FeIIHS is 3 cm3 mol-1·K, hence, the    χ M  T   for FeIIHSFeIILSFeIIHS and FeIIHSFeIIHSFeIIHS is 6 and 9 cm3 mol-1·K, respectively (Table 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl3]).

Apply this to the experimental data: below room temperature (20°C–25°C), the experimental    χ M  T   value for Zn3(1-x)Fe3(x) complexes is around 7 cm3 mol-1·K, which corresponds to 68% of the Fe    χ M  T   trimers in HS-LS-HS configuration and 32% in HS-HS-HS. Upon heating up to 400K, the experimental    χ M  T   product increases until 9 cm3 mol-1·K, consistent with a complete spin transition of the central FeII ion, resulting in a 100% HS-HS-HS FeII trimer in the sample, see Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8].
Critical: In some SCO compounds, the spin transition is accompanied by a crystallographic phase transition. This phase transition can be followed by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and by variable temperature PXRD. In our case, we performed DSC (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]) analysis and collected PXRD patterns under vacuum at different temperatures (Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]) to rule out the participation of a crystallographic phase transition.
Note: All PXRD plots are well fitted with the crystallographic data from the Fe3 and Zn3 single-crystal solution, obtaining similar refined cell parameters in all the samples.
Note: First DSC cycle (left) shows the dehydration occurring during the first heating branch, and the absence of any feature during the first cooling branch. Second cycle (middle) does not show any sign which could be related to a phase transition. Third cycle (right) is analogous to the second one.
Spin transition detection of the polyanionic trimers in the liquid state
Timing: 3 days
The spin state transition of the Fe3 in liquid state is studied by NMR spectroscopy and UV-vis absorption spectroscopy.
Preparation of the polyanionic Fe or Zn trimers solution.
Degas the water, ethylene glycol and methanol by freeze-pump-thaw cycling.
Repeat 3 times this process.
Dissolve the Fe3 powder in a specific volume of degassed water (see Table 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl3] for exact weight and volume).

Once the complex is dissolved, add a specific volume of organic diluent (3:4 water:organic solvent ratio, Table 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl4]).
table:files/protocols_protocol_2787_4.csv
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2787-Fig11.jpg
Figure 11. 1H-NMR spectra of Fe3 in D2O:CD3OD (3:4 v.v.) at 300–250 K temperature range
The 1H signals of the HS and LS species are defined as HHS and HLS, respectively.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2787-Fig12.jpg
Figure 12. Sample preparation for Fe3 spin transition characterization by Evans NMR method
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2787-Fig13.jpg
Figure 13. Evans NMR method for f Fe3
(A) 1H-NMR spectra in the 250−290 K range showing the shift in acetone 1H-NMR signals between the outer (Acetone') and inner tube (Acetone).
(B)    χ M    T vs. T graph of Fe3.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2787-Fig14.jpg
Figure 14. Representation of the set-up to read the temperature of the sample solution
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2787-Fig15.jpg
Figure 15. UV-Vis spectrometer set-up for variable temperature UV-Vis absorption measurements
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2787-Fig16.jpg
Figure 16. Difference between sample and set temperature (absolute value) during warming and cooling processes
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2787-Fig17.jpg
Figure 17. Temperature-dependence absorption spectra for Fe3 solution during warming and cooling processes
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2787-Fig18.jpg
Figure 18. Thermal evolution of the absorbance at 320 nm
Stir the resulting solution at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Critical: The solutions were prepared and maintained under an inert atmosphere to avoid the FeII oxidation. After the preparation, check if the solution is still colorless and without precipitation.
Variable temperature H-NMR spectroscopy.
Note: Variable temperature H-NMR spectroscopy can monitor the spin transition processes in solution, especially detectable in transition between FeIIHS (paramagnetic) and FeIILS (diamagnetic) ions. In general, the paramagnetism involves fast T1 relaxation times in the protons, provoking complex H-NMR spectra with wide chemical shift range and broadened signal.
Prepare 4mM of Fe3 in D2O: CD3OD (3:4 v.v.), see Table 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl3].
Optimize the experimental parameters typical of paramagnetic H-NMR spectra, in our case:
wide field range (SW = 100 ppm).
high scan number (128).

short d1 values (d1 = 1 s).
Collect the H-NMR spectra in the 200 K−300 K range.
Assign the different signals (see Figure 11[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig11]):
Broader and highly deshielded signals (23, 14, and 13 ppm at room temperature, 20°C–25°C) are attribute to the HS-HS-HS trimer (denoted as HHS).
Sharper peaks at higher magnetic fields (8.5, 4.8, and 4.4 ppm at 250 K) are attributed to HS-LS-HS configuration (denoted as HLS signals).
Evans NMR method.
Note: The paramagnetic susceptibility of Fe3 in solution was determined by NMR-based Evans measurements. The Evans method estimates the total magnetic moment of the Fe3 solution from paramagnetic shift provoked in a reference solvent (e.g. non-deuterated acetone) by the paramagnetic species.
Sample Preparation.
Use a NMR tube with a coaxial tube insert. Fill the outer with the Fe3 solution (4mM) in D2O:ethylene glycol (3:4 v.v.) and the inner tube with Zn3 solution (4mM) in D2O:ethylene glycol (3:4 v.v.).
Add non-deuterated acetone (2% v.v) to both tubes, see Figure 12[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig12].
Magnetic data interpretation.
Record the 1H-NMR spectra in a 500 MHz spectrometer in the 250–300 K range.
Identify the inner and outer acetone signal. The inner acetone will give a H-signal at lower frequency and with lower integral (Acetone) than the outer acetone (Acetone’), Figure 13[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig13]A.
Reference the inner acetone signal in all spectra at 2.05 ppm (f1).
Measure the chemical shift in acetone signals between the inner and outer tubes (f2−f1).
Determine the molar paramagnetic susceptibility from the experimentally measured shift in acetone signals by using this equation:
χ
M
=
3
δ

M
4
π
ƒ
m

where    χ M    is the molar paramagnetic susceptibility (cm3mol-1),   δ ƒ   is the frequency difference between the acetone peaks of the inner and outer tube (f(Hz) = f(ppm)·500), M the molecular weight of the paramagnetic complex (g·mol-1), f the frequency of the NMR instrument (5·10 Hz) and m the mass of the complex (g).
Plot the    χ M  T   product vs. T to obtain Figure 13[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig13]B.
Note: According to the equation    χ M  =   (  3 δ ƒ M  )   (  4 π ƒ m  )    , the magnetic susceptibility of Fe3 can be estimated from this shift (  δ ƒ  ), obtaining a    χ M    T vs T graph.
UV−vis absorption.
Note: The spin transition of Fe3 in solution can be monitored with variable temperature UV-vis spectroscopy by following the evolution of absorption band corresponding to FeII LS species.
Set-up preparation.
Use a 1 cm quartz cell with a septum screw cap and introduce a magnetic stirrer.
Place a thermocouple Pt100 temperature sensor across the septum cap.
Seal the Pt100 wire with a septum to avoid gas leaks.
Perform several vacuum-N2 flow cycles inside the cell.
Introduce the Fe3 solution in water:ethylene glycol (3:4% v.v) mixture (4mM). See section “Preparation of the polyanionic Fe or Zn trimers solution”.
Connect the temperature sensor to a temperature controller. See the set-up in Figure 14[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig14].
Place the cell with the Pt100 in a cryostat (Unisoku Scientific Instrument).
Note: The temperature can be controlled from -80°C to 100°C by using liquid nitrogen as a coolant. This cryostat is placed inside a sample compartment of Agilent 8453 diode array spectrophotometer (l = 190–1,100 nm), see Figure 15[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig15].

Set the kinetic mode in the spectrometer software (1 spectra·min-1) and manually set the temperature in the cryostat during heating and cooling processes (0.5 K min-1 – 0.1 K min-1 range scan rate).
The exact temperature in the solution was monitored by thermocouple Pt100 controller.
Critical: . It is important to monitor the exact sample temperature that correspond to each spectrum to mitigate the difference between the set and sample temperature (up to 8 degrees at low temperature 240 K) and the different thermalization during cooling and warming processes, Figure 16[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig16].
UV-Vis absorption data
The evolution of the absorption band around 320 nm is analyzed upon warming and cooling processes in 293-240 K range, Figure 17[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig17].
From these spectra, we plot the evolution of absorbance at 320 nm as a function of temperature in the warming and cooling branches obtaining hysteresis cycle describing the spin transition, Figure 18[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig18].
